I use a **single, modern 1 GW‑electric (GWe) coal plant** and a **comparable 1 GWe nuclear plant** located in the same geographic region (so they share the same population density, climate, and health baseline). | Plant type | Typical name‑plate capacity (electric) | Typical net capacity factor* | Annual electricity output | Typical location used for the example |
|------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|---------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Coal‑fired   | 1 GW (≈ 1,000 MW)                     | 75 % (modern U.S./EU plants) | 1 GW × 0.75 × 8 760 h ≈ 6.6 TWh yr⁻¹ | Midwest United States (population ≈ 2 M within 100 km) |

**Step‑by‑step calculation**

| Quantity | Calculation | Result |
|----------|-------------|--------|
| Annual electricity from the coal plant | 6.6 TWh yr⁻¹ | 6.6 TWh |
| Deaths per TWh (consensus) | 24 deaths / TWh | — |
| **Annual deaths attributable to the plant** | 6.6 TWh × 24 deaths/TWh | **≈ 158 deaths yr⁻¹** |

| Source | Approx. % of total | Approx. deaths/yr |
